title: Georgie Gardner reveals her own grandmother was duped by skincare scam using her face
text:
Georgie Gardner has warned fans about a Facebook scam that is using her image without permission to sell face creams.

Speaking on the Today show on Tuesday, the Nine presenter revealed these fraudulent ads are so convincing that her own grandmother was duped.

'This scheme is so good that my own grandmother bought the face cream that I was purportedly selling,' Georgie told co-host Tom Steinfort and Nine's finance editor Ross Greenwood.

Georgie was referring a bogus social media campaign involving fake news articles claiming she was 'stepping away from Today' to sell skincare products.

Earlier in the segment, Ross proposed that high-profile personalities should band together to stop fake ads from appearing on Facebook, saying: 'It's just plain wrong and Facebook has to be held accountable.'

Georgie agreed wholeheartedly, replying: 'I'm with you. I'm on board!'

'This scheme is so good': The Today show's Georgie Gardner has warned fans about a Facebook scam that is so convincing even her own grandmother was dumped

It's unclear whether Georgie was referring to her maternal or paternal grandmother, neither of whom she has named publicly.

It's not the first time the breakfast TV star has criticised Facebook for hosting fake ad campaigns using her image to trick users into divulging their credit card details.

In August last year, Georgie took to Instagram to blast the social media giant, writing: 'Appalled and disgusted by this scam, using my image to endorse a face cream, under the guise of a news story.

'Do not buy it and FB take responsibility as publishing platform to remove it.'

Not true! Georgie was referring a bogus social media campaign involving fake news articles claiming she was 'stepping away from Today' to sell skincare products (pictured)

She also rubbished the false ads in an opinion piece for 9Honey at the time, writing: 'For the record I just want to state that I have absolutely no association with any of these products.'

Urging fans to be vigilant with their financial details, she added: 'There have been a few different scams over the years but I'm baffled as to how it's gotten this far.

'How is it that Facebook can provide a platform that enables these scams without taking responsibility for the impact it's having?'
description: Georgie Gardner has warned fans about a Facebook scam that is using her image without permission to sell face creams.
authors: Monique Friedlander For Daily Mail Australia
